label: 山崎闇斎
本: The Cambridge History of Japan, Volume 4:  Early Modern Japan . Cambridge University Press . 1991
説明文: (1618-82).  [Neo-Confucian scholar.]  In 1655 he established a private school in Kyoto that attracted a large number of disciples.  Besides instructing students, Ansai published works by Chu Hsi and wrote commentaries on them.  He also traveled reguarly to Edo where he lectured before a number of daimyo....  The emphsis that Ansai put on the cultivation of an attitude of reverence"...(Ch: ching, J: kei or tsutsushimi), a mental state characterized by stability of mind and circumspect behavior, ...as opposed to the "plumbing of principle," is one of the distinctive features of his approach (pp. 418-419). [朱子、敬]"
